reviewText: I looked for the Road To movies a few years back with no luck. I checked back recently, and was pleased to find this collection of the first four- and, arguably, the best four- films in the series. The package is nice, and the movies are on one double-sided DVD, which is a nice change from the unnecessarily disc-heavy sets we see so often. The transfer of the movies isn't perfect, but they're old, and it's still fantastic in both sound and picture. All four movies are wonderful, though Road To Singapore is a bit slow in coming off the ground. Hope and Crosby are revered as one of the best comedy duos of all time, and this set proves why. I'm young, and I love these movies. They're great fun for all ages, and I highly recommend getting them. Especially for that price!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Widely considered the best of the series, ROAD TO UTOPIA was filmed in 1943 but not released until a year after WWII ended. References to 1943 movies that Hope and Crosby starred in separately ("Dixie" and "Let's Face It") are evidence of this picture's vintage.The insulting banter between Bing and Bob that was a "Road" trademark reached its pinnacle here. One-liners, put-downs, squelches and zingers fly at a furious pace as the two con-men partners rip each other and their foes with unparalled insouciance.Another highlight of "Road" films is a song from Dottie Lamour, and she's given a goodie this time: "Personality" may be Miss Lamour's best cinematic number. Mssrs. Hope & Crosby also delight with a vaudevillian rendition of "Put it There, Pal." Bing's hit single of "Sunday, Monday or Always" is featured, as are four others tunes.Humorist Robert Benchley as narrator makes delightful inset cameos-- sometimes the action freezes while he speaks and at others Benchley comments as things unfold. On more than one occasion, Hope (as Chester) breaks the imaginary fourth wall to address the audience."Utopia" is related in one long flashback as elderly Chester and wife Sal (Lamour) reminisce with unexpected visitor Duke (Crosby)-- neither thought Duke had survived his brave stand against a gang of Alaskan thugs. A "Gold Rush map to a mine" story is mere background to marvelous interplay between our three stars. Benchley's moments and some rather startling animated special effects that involve live animals also add to the fun.Stylistically, "Road to Utopia" holds up better than almost any of its contemporaries and is the epitome of classic comedy. Highest recommendation.TheROAD TO COLLECTIONcontains "Utopia," plus "Road to Morocco" (1942), "Road to Singapore" (1940) and "Road to Zanzibar" (1941).
summary: Chester [to Duke]: "Next time, I bring Sinatra."
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are four Road pictures in this package, all with Bing Crosby, Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour. I get the feeling Hope & Crosby made other Road pictures, but these were the ones with Dorothy Lamour. I may do some research at some point and find out.About the whole series: For one thing, when I saw these on TV as a kid, I was completely unaware of all the homosexual innuendos involved. After all, they were girl-chasers, right? I did not appreciate all the puns and in-jokes, although I did catch some of them. But the part I always did like was when they acknowledged that they were in a movie, and made jokes about the movie-making process. Of course, Dorothy Lamour was very pretty, and could sing and dance well.Anyway, here's a brief recap of all four:Road to Singapore (1940)Crosby is Josh Mallon, scion of a wealthy shipping family that does not want to get stuck behind a desk like his father. He's been on a lark with his best friend, Ace Lannigan (Hope), but comes back to San Francisco and gets roped into plans for his long-anticipated marriage to a rich society blond who really does try to be a good sport.But Josh and Ace have made a pact to avoid women (because they are always trouble) and go off to Singapore to get away from it all. Of course, there are women there, as well. Mima (Lamour) has been dancing in a club with her mother's former dance partner, a bully who uses whip and knives to make her dancing dangerous. He is also insanely jealous of Mima. But she appoints herself Josh and Ace's housekeeper, and the results are the usual non-stop confusion that Crosby & Hope came to be known for.Road to Zanzibar (1941)The con men get conned in this laugh-a-minute movie. They get in big trouble because their phony Daredevil act sets the circus big-top on fire. A wealthy eccentric pays for the damage and sells them a diamond mine. Problem is, he had no authority to sell it, as he is a "harmless" kook who has a trustee and is not permitted to sign documents. From then on, everyone assumes the diamond mine is fake, but I kept waiting for it to turn out to be real.Anyway, once they learn the kook did not have the right to sell it, they conned someone else into buying it, and with the money they got from the sale, intended to book passage back to Brooklyn. (Or was it the Bronx?) But they get scammed by two girls (Dorothy Lamour and Una Merkel) into buying Lamour from the slave market where she had supposedly been kidnapped. In fact, Merkel and the slave trader split the take; the deal was phony.Everything in this movie is phony, and everyone is trying to bluff and scam everyone else. Three guesses who comes out on top.Road to Morocco (1942)Hope and Crosby are castaways who are washed up on the shore of the Mediterranean and find their way across the desert to Morocco. There a princess (Lamour, of course) buys Hope and intends to make him her husband. That's because a soothsayer has told her that her first husband will only last one week after their marriage, but the second one will live long and prosper, have lots of beautiful children, etc. She will therefore make Sheik Mullay Kassim (Anthony Quinn) her second husband instead of her "sacrificial" first.Hope doesn't know that (a) there is this prediction, and (b) that she's really falling in love with Crosby. Most of the laughs surround the layers and layers of fakery on almost everyone's part. At least this time there's also a girl for Hope when Crosby again wins Lamour.Road to Utopia (1946)They are con men again, but of course they get into a peck of trouble. This time Crosby wants to go to Alaska, where there is a gold rush going on, but Hope wants to return to New York and open a Turkish bath. Of course, they end up on the ship to Alaska. Dorothy Lamour is the girl who was supposed to inherit the gold mine that was on the map stolen from an old man (her father? her uncle?) by two killers who shot him for possession of the map. The killers are on the same ship as Hope and Crosby, who lost all their money and were supposed to pay their passage by working for the ship captain, then be taken back to San Francisco. But they accidentally find the map of the gold mine, overpower the killers and tie them up in their stateroom, and assume their identities.Lamour has also come north to try to recover her inheritance, and goes to a crooked lawyer who is only interested in getting the map and stealing her mine. There are some incredibly funny scenes in this film, probably the best of the four. Bob Hope making love to a bear is one of the best.I give the whole set three stars, recognizing that some of my pleasure in these films is based on childhood memories.

reviewText: Dorothy Lamour is the film star of my dreams. Sweet and lovely, gentle and kind, greatly talented, humorous and good, that's the way she seems to me. Her face, her eyes, her form. Unbrassy, unpushy, her voice soft and low --- an excellent thing in woman --- beautiful without being dull, smart without being bossy. If ever there was a woman like that, she was that woman. I can't say I've ever met one, though. And on this disc you get four for the price of one. Bob and Bing were ok, but neither of them deserved her.

reviewText: This is a collection of classic pure clean fun romps from a duo the likes of which we will never see again. Bob Hope's masterful one-liners are legion, but Bing Crosby was the perfect complement to him. The DVD is good quality, and although the movies here presented are B&W (as were almost all of the Road Series) the photography well reflects the exotic settings.

reviewText: Bob Hope and Bing Crosby + Dorothy Lamour made six "Road" pictures for Paramount between 1941 and 1953:1) Road to Singapore - 19412) Road to Zanzibar - 19403) Road to Morocco - 19424) Road to Utopia - 19465) Road to Rio - 19476) Road to Bali - 1953 (the only one in color)Paramount's pre-1948 catalog is now owned by Universal, which has a spotty record of reissuing these wonderful films on DVD.Films 1-4 are available in three different editions:Best, but most expensive, is 4 movies on 4 DVDs (2002):Bob Hope Tribute Collection - The Road Show Series (The Road to Morocco / The Road to Singapore / The Road to Utopia / The Road to Zanzibar)(available separately).Worst is 4 movies on 1 double-sided DVD (2004). REVIEWED HERE.Double-sided DVDs fail at an alarming rate.The most recent edition (2012) isThe Bob Hope and Bing Crosby Road to Comedy CollectionTwo DVDs, with a double feature on one side of each disc (not double-sided, thank God).Picture quality is equivalent to the 2002 4 disc version, but the price is a lot less.Some of the "extras" from the 2002 4 disc version were left out. The only important loss was the movie trailers.All three versions are closed-captioned.At the price, this is the new recommended version.Annoyingly, films 5 and 6 were left out of each collection.Paramount stupidly allowed the copyright to expire on these films, so they are now in the Public Domain.Lots of inexpensive copies are available on DVD from various cheapo labels.The situation was somewhat rectified in 2010 when Shout Factory released an authorized 3 DVD collection:The Bob Hope Collection (The Lemon Drop Kid / Road to Bali / Road to Rio / My Favorite Brunette / The Seven Little Foys)Less expensive, almost as good:Road to Bali / Road to RioI only wish Universal had the sense to issue the six film collection complete in a nice box on 3 double-feature DVDs (NOT 2-sided!).Maybe even blu-ray.P.S. Missing from my list is the seventh film, The Road to Hong Kong (1962), but it is owned by MGM, not Universal:The Road to Hong Kong- or -Bob Hope MGM Movie Legends Collection (Alias Jesse James/Boy, Did I Get the Wrong Number/The Facts of Life/I'll Take Sweden/The Princess and the Pirate/The Road to Hong Kong/They've Got Me Covered)The boys are a bit long-in-the tooth (Dorothy Lamour is reduced to a cameo).Not as good as the first six, but still worth a look.P.P.S. All seven films are available in a boxed set, but its only available in the United Kingdom (issued in 2005).They are PAL, region 2 DVDs, which means they won't play on 99% of American TVs.Available on Amazon UK (amazon.co.uk):ASIN: B0009W09GEYou will need a region-free DVD player, which are gray market (not covered by manufacturer's warranty).Look up "region free DVD player" on the Amazon search bar.
summary: HOW TO BUY THE FIRST 4 ROAD PICTURES - READ THIS BEFORE BUYING

reviewText: "... Singapore" - 3 - Josh and Ace are through pursing women; Ace avoids a shotgun wedding and Josh dodges a marriage with a woman with eyes set more on his future inheritance than on him.  They escape on a ship to Singapore but get off on Kaigoon, where they rescue a beautiful woman from her cruel dance partner.  They take her in and their vow to quit pursing women lasts as long as a New Year's resolution . . . ."... Zanzibar" - 4 - Chuck and Fearless are on the run after their death-defying act sets the circus tent on fire.  They escape by rail and eventually end up at a port city.  Fearless is ready to sail home but Chuck takes their money and buys a worthless deed to a diamond mine and Fearless, in-turn, sells it to some very bad men.  They escape by river boat into the interior of Africa where they meet two women who scheme to remove the money from their wallets . . . ."... Morocco" - 5 - Geoffrey and Orville escape a sinking ship and land in Morocco.  They cross the desert to Karameesh.  Starving, they order a big meal at a cafe; one problem: no money.  So, naturally, Geoffrey sells Orville to a man at the next table.  Orville is taken to Princess Shalmar to be married; Orville is willing - until he finds out why . . . ."... Utopia" - 3 - Duke and Chester have a profitable act: theater patrons place their money in a magic "Ghost-O" box in the hopes their money will increase in value, but when their phony act is exposed, they escape to Alaska by ship.  While they are cleaning the cabin of two murderers, they discover a map to a gold mine belonging to a beautiful gal named Sal . . . .Double-sided disc: no problems.  Picture (DVD): 3 to 3.5, grainy.

reviewText: If you don't like classic comedy, you're not going to like this either.  But for me, this is my first stop when I need to take a break from the Marx Brothers (who I watch way too much).  These films are exhibit A for Bob Hope's comedic talents, and Bing's cooler than you or I will ever be.  Plus with Bing around, I'm actually happy to listen when the songs come, which is not the case for most 30's and 40's Hollywood films.  Morocco is my favorite, but any of these four films can brighten a dark day.  There are a few decent extras on this set, and for $20 it's a steal.  If you're willing to watch a comedy made before "Animal House," you should go ahead and take the plunge into Hope and Crosby's world.

reviewText: There are many great comedies nowadays, but there are very few great comedy teams.  In the old days, you could have the Three Stooges, the Marx Brothers, Laurel and Hardy or Abbott and Costello:  teams that were greater than the sum of their parts. (What was Abbott without Costello or Moe without Curly and Larry?)  Bob Hope and Bing Crosby, on the other hand, each were successful on their own, yet they are also recognized as a team in a way that even modern combinations like Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson are not.  And the series of films that made them a famous team were the Road Pictures, the first four (of seven) of which are on the DVD On the Road with Bob Hope.Actually, the Hope/Crosby team was actually a trio, with Dorothy Lamour as the woman who always came between the two.  In the first Road movie, Road to Singapore, she is an island girl taken in by the two of them after they get her away from her nasty employer.  The two are sailors fleeing commitment in the U.S. by taking refuge on a tropical island.  In the second movie, Road to Zanzibar, they are showmen in Africa who escort Lamour and Una Merkel through the jungle, unaware that the two women are actually con artists.In Road to Morocco, the two find themselves in a desert nation.  Crosby sells Hope into slavery, which turns out to be a lot better than it sounds, when it turns out he has to marry a princess played by Lamour.  What Hope doesn't know is that her first husband is destined to die, clearing the way for a long second marriage; what Lamour doesn't know is that the prediction is based on faulty information.  Though Hope always seems to lose Lamour to Crosby by the end of the movie, Road to Utopia shows Hope and Lamour old and long-married before flashing back to a time when they were in Alaska looking for a gold mine.Plot is almost incidental in these movies, merely a means to move from one gag to another.  Although I doubt they were the first to do so, they often seem to recognize that they are in movies.  For example, in Road to Utopia, Hope calls a mountain his bread-and-butter: it suddenly gets a circle of stars and becomes the Paramount logo.  Anything can happen - even animals talk - and it is all a lot of fun.  Not every joke works, but Hope and Crosby's chemistry carry the films.  For some silly, old-fashioned movie comedy, this foursome fits the bill nicely.

reviewText: For you young whippersnappers who have never seen a Hope-Crosby "Road" picture, there's a reason these are considered to be classics. No one has ever done a better "buddy" movie. NOBODY. While many of the gags will only resonate with those old enough to get the topical references, there are plenty of timeless jokes that will make people of any age laugh. The chemistry between Hope, Crosby and Lamour is perfect and watching these films you can't help but wish you had such friends to go on the "Road" with. My only gripes with this collection is that all 4 films are on one double-sided disc (I prefer separate discs); there are no commentaries or interviews in the special features; and of course, like all Hope-Crosby fans, I wish all 7 "Road Pictures" were fully restored and available in one collector set. Maybe someday...

reviewText: In the last couple of years I have started to really appreciate the talent of Hope and Crosby.  These movies are very funny and they do stand the test of time.  You just have to give them a chance.  It's not a modern Seinfeld or Chappell type humor, but it is deeply funny and influential.  For example, Woody Allen has stated he was influenced by Bob Hope.  If you watch these movies and then some of Allen's early movies you'll see that Allen "almost" mimics Hope.  I am really suprised that so few people have reviewed this set.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I grew up watching and loving The Three Stooges.  I don't mind a good slapstick from time to time.  I had heard of the famous "road" movies of Hope and Crosby.  My wife and I are always up for some old school filmology.  And so it was that I went into watching these road movies with some decent expectations of genuine laughs and liking the main stars (I've liked them in plenty of other things).  I ended up being quickly disappointed.  Beginning with "The Road To Singapore" I grew to quickly dislike the relationship between Hope and Crosby.  I understand that this was at the heart of these movies but the constant usury between the two, with Bing always the older and always getting the girl, did not tickle my funny bone.  And Hope's constant mugging!  Ugh.  The constant selling out your friend for money was tiring.  After watching all four I felt that "The Road to Zanzibar" was only slightly better than "Singapore", with a female couple parralleling Hope and Crosby's schtick.  "Road to Morocco" was the best of the bunch, with the two giving some nods and winks to the camera.  "Utopia" followed the formula but threw in some (for the time) salacious commentary as the third wall was frequently broken.  The relationships that they fell into with Dorothy Lamour and others were never close to real--I've seen lovebirds take longer to fall for each other than these pairs!  I'm sorry to say that I, nor my wife, enjoyed these movies.

reviewText: This collection of the first four Road movies is a great release.  These movies still hold up quite well and are still very funny.  The road to Utopia is my favorite but the other three included are also good.  I am a big fan of Dorothy Lamour and she definitely shines in these films.  This is some of her most memorable work and a must have for Lamour fans.  There might not be many bells and whistles with this set but for such a good price and seeing as how you get four movies it's well worth it.
